Chapter 7: The Noble and Virtuous, Part 1 of the MahÄlalikÄ SÅ«tra The Buddha said:

Why is it called noble?

What are the three things?

First, when sitting together with the elders, whether in the hall or walking in the alleys and on the roads, and sitting together with the elders, they praise the noble person's good conduct together.
The noble person thinks:
'May the multitude praise people, saying 'Excellent!'
If there are such noble people, their minds are immediately at ease. Hearing these words, their minds are also joyful and their bodies are at ease.

Sometimes the noble people see thieves who are caught by the county officials, severely tortured, bound with iron chains, their hands and feet cut off, their bodies dismembered, their ears and noses cut off, whipped with bamboo sticks, their bodies cut into pieces, fed to tigers and wolves. Some are trampled to death by elephants, some are wrapped in sacks and burned, some are steamed to death, some are starved to death, and some are executed outside the city.
When the noble people see this, they think:
I do not do evil. The king only takes evil people. What should I worry about?
Until I grow old, I will not worry about the county officials.
Because of this, the noble people are joyful in their hearts.

The thoughts of the high-minded are good, their speech is good, and their actions are good. If they become ill and weak and are confined to bed, the good they did when strong appears before their eyes.

People who do not kill, do not take others' possessions, do not violate others' spouses, do not deceive, do not engage in slander, do not speak harshly, do not lie, do not envy, and do not covet, who believe in doing good and receiving good, and doing evil and receiving evil,

The sick person thinks to themselves:
Is it because of the good I did when strong that all the goodness comes to see me on the path? Even if I die, I will ascend to heaven and be among the good people.
For these three reasons, the high-minded person's mind is joyful and their body is at ease.
The Buddha said:
Even if a noble person knows that by doing good he will obtain good, he will no longer fear birth and death, and there is nothing to rely on.
The noble person always thinks of leaving the evil body, which contains bones, blood, impurities, and foul places, and wishes to die early and take on a good body.
